facts.text: Suit for partition instituted on April 2, 1942, in Court of District Munsif, Ongole, on behalf of minor Kakumanu Ramanna by his maternal grandfather Rangayya as next friend.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises out of a suit for partition of joint family properties instituted on April 2, 1942, in the Court of the District Munsif, Ongole, on behalf of one Kakumanu Ramanna, a minor of the age of about 2 1/2 years by his material grandfather, Rangayya, as his next friend.

facts.text: Kakumanu Ramanna was a minor of about 2 1/2 years old at time of suit institution.

anchor.surface_text: on behalf of one Kakumanu Ramanna, a minor of the age of about 2 1/2 years by his material grandfather, Rangayya, as his next friend.

facts.text: First defendant is father of plaintiff Kakumanu Ramanna.

anchor.surface_text: The first defendant is his father. The second and third defendants are the sons of the first defendant by his deceased first wife.

facts.text: Second and third defendants are sons of first defendant by his deceased first wife.

anchor.surface_text: The first defendant is his father. The second and third defendants are the sons of the first defendant by his deceased first wife. The fourth defendant is the second wife of the first defendant and the mother of the plaintiff-.

facts.text: Fourth defendant is second wife of first defendant and mother of plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: The fourth defendant is the second wife of the first defendant and the mother of the plaintiff-. The fifth defendant is the daugther of the first defendant by the fourth defendant.

facts.text: Fifth defendant is daughter of first defendant by fourth defendant.

anchor.surface_text: The fifth defendant is the daugther of the first defendant by the fourth defendant. In the plaint, three grounds were put forward as to why the minor plaintiff should have partition

facts.text: Plaint alleged ill-treatment of plaintiff's mother and neglect to maintain her and children; held not established by District Munsif and Subordinate Judge.

anchor.surface_text: In the plaint, three grounds were put forward as to why the minor plaintiff should have partition  1  It was said that the mother of the plaintiff was ill-treated, and there was neglect to maintain her and her children. Both the District Munsif and the Subordinate Judge on appeal, held that this had number been established,

facts.text: Sale of family properties to Akkul Venkatasubba Reddi for Rs. 2,300 on May 9, 1939; alleged no necessity and to injure plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: 2  It was then said that there had been a sale of the family properties to one Akkul Venkatasubba Reddi for Rs. 2,300, that there was numbernecessity for that sale, and that its object was only to injure the plaintiff. That sale is dated May 9, 1939.

facts.text: Item 2 purchased on June 1, 1938, and item 11 on June 14, 1939, with joint family funds but sale deeds in names of second and third defendants to diminish plaintiff's assets.

anchor.surface_text: 3  Lastly, it was alleged that item 2 had been purchased on June 1, 1938, and item 11 on June 14, 1939, with joint family 1251 funds, but that the sale deeds had been taken in the names of the second and third defendants with a view to diminish the assets available to the plaintiff.

facts.text: Plaint stated family in good circumstances with no debts.

anchor.surface_text: In addition to these allegations, it was also stated in the plaint that the family was in good circumstances, and that there were numberdebts owing by it.

facts.text: Defendants filed written statements on June 20, 1942, claiming purchases of items 2 and 11 with separate funds of second and third defendants, and family debts of Rs. 2,600.

anchor.surface_text: On June 20, 1942, the defendants filed their written statements, wherein they claimed that the purchase of items 2 and 11 had been made with the separate funds of the second and third defendants, and that the joint family had numbertitle to them. They further alleged that the family had debts to the extent of Rs. 2,600.

facts.text: Minor plaintiff Kakumanu Ramanna died sometime in January 1943; his mother (fourth defendant) recorded as legal representative and transposed as second plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime in January 1943, the minor plaintiff died, and his mother who was the fourth defendant was recorded as his legal representative, and transposed as the second plaintiff.

facts.text: First plaintiff born on December 20, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: At the rehearing, it ,as proved that the first plaintiff was born on December 20, 1939.

facts.text: District Munsif held sale to Akkul Venkatasubba Reddi and purchases of items 2 and 11 anterior to birth of minor plaintiff, no cause of action for partition.

anchor.surface_text: On that, the District Munsif held that the sale of the family properties to Akkul Venkatasubba Reddi and the purchase of items 2 and II in the names of the second and third defendants having been anterior to the birth of the minor plaintiff, numbercause of action for partition companyld be founded thereon.

facts.text: District Munsif held on evidence that purchases of items 2 and 11 not shown with separate funds, belong to joint family.

anchor.surface_text: The District Munsif also held on the evidence that the purchase of items 2 and 11 was number shown to have been made with separate funds, and that therefore they belonged to the joint family

facts.text: District Munsif held family owed no debts, allegations contra not made out; but no cause of action for partition, suit dismissed on December 23, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: and further that the family owed numberdebts and that the allegations companytra in the statements were number made out. But he held, however, that this did number furnish a cause of action for partition. In the result, he dismissed the suit.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge of Bapatla affirmed findings that items 2 and 11 belong to joint family, no debts; suit not maintainable as transactions prior to birth, dismissed appeal on January 28, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: There was an appeal against this judgment to the Court of the Subordinate Judge of Bapatla, who affirmed the findings of the District Munsif that items 2 and 11 belonged to the joint, family, and that there were numberdebts owing by it. But he also agreed with him that as the sale and purchases in question were prior to the birth of the minor plaintiff,

facts.text: Madras High Court in Second Appeal No. 1815 of 1949 by Satyanarayana Rao J. held defendants falsely claimed items 2 and 11 separate, adverse to minor, suit beneficial, granted preliminary decree for partition on April 10, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The second plaintiff took the matter in second appeal to the High Court of Madras, and that was heard by Satyanarayana Rao J. who held that as the defendants had falsely claimed that items 2 and 11 were the separate properties of the second and third defendants, their interest was adverse to that of the minor and that the suit for partition was clearly beneficial to him. He accordingly granted a preliminary decree for partition.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court by special leave under Art. 136 against High Court decree.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 326 of 1955. 1250 Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated April 10, 1953, of the Madras High Court in Second Appeal No. 1815 of 1949,

facts.text: Defendants 1 to 3 in written statements denied title of plaintiff to items 2 and 11, adduced evidence at trial that separate properties of 2 and 3.

anchor.surface_text: In the written statements which were filed shortly after the institution of the suit while the first plaintiff was alive, defendants I to 3 companybined to deny his title to items 2 and I 1, and at the trial, they adduced evidence in support of their companytention that they were the separate properties of defendants 2 and 3.

facts.text: Both lower courts concurrently held against defendants on issues of items 2 and 11 being separate and existence of debts.

anchor.surface_text: Even in the Court of Appeal, the defendants persisted in pressing this claim, and further maintained that the joint family had debts, and both the companyrts below had companycurrently held against them on these issues.

facts.text: Supreme Court accepts High Court finding that suit instituted for benefit of minor plaintiff.

Under the Mitakshara law, the right, of a coparcener to share in the joint family properties arises on his birth, and that right carries with it the right to be maintained out of those properties suitably to the status of the family so long as the family is joint and to have a partition and separate possession of his share, should he make a demand for it.

anchor.surface_text: We accept the finding of the High Court that the suit was instituted for the benefit of the minor plaintiff, and in that view, we proceed to consider the second question raised by the learned Attorney-General

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts misdirected by treating prior transactions as barring cause of action rather than assessing post-birth adverse conduct by defendants denying minor's title to items 2 and 11 and claiming debts.

holdings.text: The finding of the Subordinate Judge that no cause of action for partition could be founded on transactions prior to minor's birth is a clear misdirection.

anchor.surface_text: But it must be observed that the finding of the Subordinate Judge was only that as the impugned sale and purchases were made before the minor plaintiff was born, no cause of action for partition could be founded by him thereon, and that, in our opinion, is a clear misdirection.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Transactions show adverse intent when used post-birth to deny minor's rights; benefit assessed on conduct justifying partition, not timing of transactions.

holdings.text: A suit for partition instituted on behalf of a minor coparcener by his next friend effects a severance in status from the date of the suit if the court holds it beneficial to the minor.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the respondents, on the other hand, is that a suit for partition instituted on behalf of a minor coparcener stands on the same footing as a similar suit filed by an adult coparcener, with this difference that if the suit is held by the court not to have been instituted for the benefit

holdings.reasoning_summary: Minor coparcener rights same as adult under Mitakshara; next friend expresses unequivocal intention per Girja Bai; court approves as parens patriae, severance relates back; distinguishes Chelimi Chetty as erroneous; follows Rangasayi, Kawal Nain.

holdings.text: The suit for partition does not abate on the death of the minor plaintiff before the court decides benefit; legal representative may continue and prove benefit.

anchor.surface_text: the action abated and could not be continued by his mother as his legal representative. On the first question, the contention of the appellants is that it is a pure question of fact whether the institution of a suit is for the benefit of a minor or not,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Severance conditional on benefit finding but effective from suit date; legal rep steps in to establish benefit; partition suit survives as property right, not personal.

holdings.text: The ratio decidendi of Chelimi Chetty v. Subbamma that power to divide minor from coparceners rests only with court is erroneous.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the ratio of the decision in Chelimi Chetty v. Subbamma -and it is this decision that was followed in Lalta Prasads Case , Hari Singh v. Pritam Singh and Chhotabhai v. Dadabhai -is that the power to bring about a division between a minor and his coparceners rests only with the court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court approves next friend's intention, does not originate it; analogous to extra-court partitions by relations binding if beneficial.

holdings.text: Courts exercise inherent parens patriae jurisdiction to ensure partition suit by minor's next friend is beneficial, recognizing pre-existing right from suit institution.

anchor.surface_text: the Sovereign as parens patriae has the power, and is indeed under a duty to protect the interests of minors, and that function has devolved on the courts. In the discharge of that function, therefore, they have the power to control all proceedings before them wherein minors are concerned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inherent power over minors independent of Hindu law; approves action without creating new right.

holdings.text: The maxim actio personalis moritur cum persona does not apply to partition suits as they concern property rights, not personal wrongs.

anchor.surface_text: the suit must abate on the principle of the maxim, actio personalis moritur cum persona. But that maxim has application only when the action is one for damages for a personal wrong, and as a suit for partition is a suit for property, the rule in question has no application to it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Partition is proprietary action surviving death; follows Rangasayi and Mandliprasad.

holdings.text: Items 2 and 11 belong to joint family; not purchased with separate funds of defendants 2 and 3; family owes no debts.

anchor.surface_text: The District Munsif also held on the evidence that the purchase of items 2 and 11 was not shown to have been made with separate funds, and that therefore they belonged to the joint family and further that the family owed no debts and that the allegations contra in the statements were not made out.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent findings of lower courts accepted; evidence insufficient for separate funds or debts.
